H0.text: Metamorphic rocks form when an existing rock is changed by heat or pressure.

H1.text: Molten rocks form when an existing rock is changed by heat or pressure.

H2.text: Igneous rocks are the rocks that form when an existing rock is changed by heat or pressure.

H3.text: Sediments are the type of rocks that form when an existing rock is changed by heat or pressure.

A4.text: Metamorphic rocks arise from the transformation of existing rock to new types of rock in a process called metamorphism. The original rock (protolith) is subjected to temperatures greater than 150 to 200 °C (300 to 400 °F) and, often, elevated pressure of 100 megapascals (1,000 bar) or more, causing profound physical or chemical changes.

A5.text: Sedimentary rocks form from sediments eroded from existing rock or precipitated chemically from bodies of water.
